Comment:
My opponent gave me a hard fight, but I managed to see the opportunity for a Smothered Mate, and it got there.  So, this annotation describes what to look for in setting up a SM.
The game starts with my usual opening, d4.  Typically, I play a Stonewall (e3 after ....d5 and then setting up a pawn structure with pawns at c3, d4, e3, and f4 with an outpost for the KN at e5).  

Here, I see I went into something that I am, frankly, less familiar with.  [DEAR READER:  I MADE A MISTAKE AND ANNOTATED AS IF I WERE PLAYING WHITE.... I DISCOVERED THE ERROR AT MOVE 11 OR SO AND CHANGED THE POINT OF VIEW OF THE NARRATIVE AT THAT POINT.]
He might be going for some sort of Nimzo Indian.
Queens Gambit.  I studied it 40 years ago or more (I'm 65), and play it by instinct and feel.  The last time I read a chess book was quite a while ago.
White would love it if Black chose to trade his d pawn for White's c pawn.
White would love it if Black chose to trade his d pawn for White's c pawn.
White would love it if Black chose to trade his d pawn for White's c pawn.
Unpinning immediately.  One of the most important lessons I learned in chess -- and in life -- is "make necessary moves first."  (like castling)
Unpinning immediately.  One of the most important lessons I learned in chess -- and in life -- is "make necessary moves first."  (like castling)

Black read my mind.
Black adds tension to the Centre.  (I spelled it the old fashioned way on purpose.)
Black adds tension to the Centre.  (I spelled it the old fashioned way on purpose.)

As I play this back, now, I'm wondering what I was thinking?  I would have thought Be2 or Bd3 would be better.  It could be preferable to leave the center tension where it is, and get my King safely castled ASAP.
After this series of exchanges, the center is half open, White is prepared to castle, and seems better developed overall.

Perhaps Black just doesn't want White to take a stab at occupying b5, or perhaps he intends b7-b5.  
White doesn't like his Bishop on d2, or the unprotected Bishop on c4.

Hmmmm.  I don't remember exactly why I made this move.  Maybe it was to give the d2 Bishop some scope, or to control d5 and/or to push d4-d5.
It does all of those things.

Oops.  A funny thing just happened:  I just realized that I am BLACK in this game!  

Oh well.  I will now continue the annotation from Black's perspective.
Brilliant!  Puts pressure on the Kingside defense.
Black removes a key defender, and lures the Q to a less than optimal spot.
Black removes a key defender, and lures the Q to a less than optimal spot.
Black removes a key defender, and lures the Q to a less than optimal spot.
This must be a mistake.  To have doubled e pawns is a long-term, permanent liability.  White should have retaken with the Queen.
This must be a mistake.  To have doubled e pawns is a long-term, permanent liability.  White should have retaken with the Queen.
Of course.  This makes the d file available for a Rook, and makes White do something about the loose Bishop.  A problem for Black is the undeveloped Bishop and QR.

The aesthetics of White's position is not good, and the pawn defense of the B worsens this impression.  The Bishop, on the a2-g8 diagonal is "biting on granite," as they say, would have been better off defending the pawn on e4 ("over protection")
Makes room for the Queen Bishop with a very powerful move obviously planned.

A little tit for tat.  This position gives the players a lot of things to think about.
